election_record.label: New York 1813 Lieutenant Governor

overview.note: The New-York Evening Post (New York, NY), New-York Spectator (New York, NY), Commercial Advertiser (New York, NY), Mercantile Advertiser (New York, NY), National Advocate (New York, NY), The Geneva Gazette (Geneva, NY), Ontario Repository, and Western Advertiser (Canandaigua, NY), and The Statesman use the spelling Taylor for John Tayler.

sub_unit.name: Brooklyn
sub_unit.note: "Brooklyn Federal majorities -- Governor 18 -- Lieut. Governor 23 -- Senator, 27." Long-Island Star (Brooklyn, NY). May 5, 1813.

sub_unit.name: New York
sub_unit.note: The New-York Evening Post (New York, NY), May 1, The Columbian (New York, NY), May 3, and The Columbian. (For the Country) (New York, NY), May 5, report 1605 votes for John Tayler in New York County; however, the sum of totals per ward is 1614.

"In the city and county of New-York the average federal majority on the Assembly ticket is 140. The majority for Governor, is 373, for Lieut. Governor, 395, for Senator, 395." Long-Island Star (Brooklyn, NY). May 5, 1813.

"City Election -- We are now able to gratify the public curiosity with a compleat return of this city for Governor, Lieut. Governor, Senator and Members of Assembly. The result is auspicious to the cause of Peace, Liberty and Commerce. When we consider the immense patronage of the general government and the state government which has been brought to bear upon this city on occasion, and when we take into the account, that besides open and know opponents, whom we could see and resist, we have had to contend with secret and unknown enemies wearing the guise of friends; -- 'a fawning treachery against which no prudence can guard, no courage defend' -- surely our success may justly be regarded as a great victory." New-York Evening Post (New York, NY). May 1, 1813.

" 'The patronge of the general government' has given the federalists the assembly ticket in New-York. In assigning this patronage as the cause of the diminution of the federal majority, there is a mistake. It has sent two or three hundred ship-carpenters, boat-builders, riggers, andc to Sacket's-Harbor and Black Rock, sufficient to have carried in the republican ticket. It has induced, if this sacrifice to patriotism can be called patronage, several hundred republican electors to enlist in the volunteer corps for the defence of the city and harbor, and thus given the federalists the election. And a considerable loss has been sustained by the republicans in privateers, probably enough to have turned the election--though we don't mean to say that in this there is any governmental patronage, as the fact happens to be rather the reverse. At any rate the federalists have not suffered in the election by any of this patronage, while the republicans have lost hundreds of votes by it." The Columbian (New York, NY). May 3, 1813.

sub_unit.name: Ten
sub_unit.note: The Statesman (For the Country) (New York, NY), May 4, and New-York Spectator (New York, NY), May 5, report 216 votes for John Tayler in Ward 10.

sub_unit.name: Queens
sub_unit.note: Long-Island Star (Brooklyn, NY), May 5, reports 982 votes for George Huntington in Flushing.

sub_unit.name: Flushing
sub_unit.note: Long-Island Star (Brooklyn, NY), May 5, reports 77 votes for George Huntington in Flushing.

sub_unit.name: Newtown
sub_unit.note: In transcribing the results in Newtown, Queens County, the election official recording the votes listed Jonathan Dayton twice, once correctly as the Republican candidate for State Senator in the Southern District, and then incorrectly as the Republican candidate for Lieutenant Governor. This mistake made its way into the Official Canvass, which reported 151 votes for Jonathan Dayton in Queens County for Lieutenant Governor. That is, however, incorrect, as the various newspaper returns for Queens County all reported that John Tayler, the Republican candidate for Lieutenant Governor did in fact receive 151 votes in Newtown and 679 in the entire county.

sub_unit.name: Suffolk
sub_unit.note: National Advocate (New York, NY), May 19, Long-Island Star (Brooklyn, NY), May 19, The Columbian (New York, NY), May 21, and The Columbian. (For the Country) (New York, NY), May 22, report 540 votes for George Huntington in Suffolk County.

sub_unit.name: Westchester
sub_unit.note: National Advocate (New York, NY), May 11, The Columbian (New York, NY), May 11, and The New-York Statesman (Albany, NY), May 12, report 1059 votes for John Tayler in Westchester County.

sub_unit.name: Greenburgh
sub_unit.note: George Huntington received 102 votes as George Hunting.

sub_unit.name: Orange
sub_unit.note: Political Index (Newburgh, NY) reports 701 votes for George Huntington in Orange County.

sub_unit.name: Deerpark
sub_unit.note: Political Index (Newburgh, NY) reports 17 votes for George Huntington in Deerpark.

sub_unit.name: Newburgh
sub_unit.note: Political Index (Newburgh, NY) reports 66 votes for George Huntington in Newburgh.

sub_unit.name: Ulster
sub_unit.note: The Commercial Advertiser (New York, NY), May 12, and New-York Spectator (New York, NY), May 15, report 1122 votes for John Tayler in Ulster County.

The Columbian (New York, NY), May 14, and The Columbian. (For the Country) (New York, NY), May 15, report 1026 votes for George Huntington in Ulster County; however, the sum of totals per town is 1032.

sub_unit.name: Marlborough
sub_unit.note: The Columbian (New York, NY), May 14, and The Columbian. (For the Country) (New York, NY), May 15, report 45 votes for George Huntington in Marlborough.

sub_unit.name: Shawangunk
sub_unit.note: The Columbian (New York, NY), May 14, and The Columbian. (For the Country) (New York, NY), May 15, report 65 votes for George Huntington in Shawangunk.

sub_unit.name: Mooers
sub_unit.note: The New-York Evening Post (New York, NY), May 12, Commercial Advertiser (New York, NY), May 13, and New-York Spectator (New York, NY), May 15, do not list Mooers in their vote breakdowns for Clinton County.

sub_unit.name: Rensselaer
sub_unit.note: Lansingburgh Gazette, May 11, reports 1236 votes for John Tayler in Rensselaer County; however, the sum of totals per town is 1237.

sub_unit.name: Pittstown
sub_unit.note: Lansingburgh Gazette, May 11, reports 196 votes for John Tayler in Pittstown.

sub_unit.name: Saratoga
sub_unit.note: The Independent American (Ballston Spa, NY), Commercial Advertiser (New York, NY), May 21, and New-York Spectator (New York, NY), May 29, report 1661 votes for John Tayler in Saratoga County.

sub_unit.name: Athol
sub_unit.note: Returns for Athol are sometimes listed under the town name Thurman.

sub_unit.name: Washington
sub_unit.note: The Albany Register (Albany, NY), June 8, reports 1695 votes for George Huntington in Washington County.

sub_unit.name: Cayuga
sub_unit.note: The Albany Register (Albany, NY), June 8, reports 844 votes for George Huntington in Cayuga County.

sub_unit.name: Hanover
sub_unit.note: John Tayler received 1 vote as John Taylar.

sub_unit.name: Virgil
sub_unit.note: In Virgil, 13 votes for Daniel D. Tompkins and John Tayler were not counted, since the office for which they were running was not designated.

sub_unit.name: Oneida
sub_unit.note: The Columbian Gazette (Utica, NY), The Columbian (New York, NY), May 18, and The Columbian. (For the Country) (New York, NY), May 19, report 1914 votes for John Tayler in Oneida County.

The Columbian (New York, NY), May 18, and The Columbian. (For the Country) (New York, NY), May 19, report 2649 votes for George Huntington in Oneida County; however, the sum of totals per town is 2639.

sub_unit.name: Hector
sub_unit.note: John Tayler received 3 votes as John Tyler and 1 vote as Taylor.

sub_unit.name: Steuben
sub_unit.note: The Official State Wide Canvass of votes lists 218 votes for George Huntington in Steuben County.

election_record.reference: Original Election Books. Steuben County Court House, Bath.
Tompkins Town Records. Delaware County Court House, Delhi.
